keyTakeAways: A South Korean elementary school teacher, Myeong Jae-wan, was sentenced to life in prison for fatally stabbing an eight-year-old student, Kim Hae-neul, in Daejeon in February 2025.
Myeong had previously requested a six-month leave of absence due to depression, but returned to school just 20 days later after being cleared by a doctor.
Myeong displayed violent behavior prior to the stabbing, including putting another teacher in a headlock, and was visited by education officials after that incident.
Myeong told police she had bought a weapon to kill herself and a random child, luring the victim into the media room before attacking her.
Kim Hae-neul was reported missing when her bus driver noted her absence and was later found with stab wounds in the school.
Myeong sustained a neck wound, possibly self-inflicted, which was treated in the hospital.

Prosecutors initially sought the death penalty due to the victim’s family’s request and the severity of the crime, but the court deemed the risk of reoffending high but could not confirm it as sufficient for execution.
Myeong expressed remorse through dozens of letters submitted to the court and stated she would reflect on her mistakes for life.
The court emphasized that as an elementary school teacher, Myeong had a duty to protect students, and her failure to do so was deeply concerning.
Myeong has been ordered to wear an electronic location tracking device for 30 years as a condition of her sentence.
South Korean leaders called for enhanced safety measures in schools to prevent similar incidents in the future.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A South Korean elementary school teacher, Myeong Jae-wan, was sentenced to life in prison for fatally stabbing an eight-year-old student, Kim Hae-neul, in Daejeon in February 2025. The incident occurred after Myeong lured the child into a classroom media room, where she attacked her with a weapon she had purchased. Myeong had previously taken a six-month leave due to depression, returned to school just 20 days later after being cleared by a doctor, and displayed violent behavior, including putting another teacher in a headlock. Police found that Myeong had planned to kill herself and a random child, and that she sustained a neck wound possibly self-inflicted. While prosecutors initially sought the death penalty due to the victim’s family’s request, the court ruled that the risk of reoffending was high but not conclusive, opting for life imprisonment. Myeong expressed deep remorse through dozens of letters and stated she would reflect on her mistakes. She has been required to wear an electronic tracking device for 30 years. The case prompted national outcry and led South Korean leaders to call for new safety measures in schools to prevent similar tragedies.
title: South Korea: Teacher who fatally stabbed student jailed for life
